attributes.comment:
Catholic Charities Refugee Resettlement Program is helping Department of State
and Department of Homeland Security to administer the Federal Refugee
Resettlement program.(http://www.acf.hhs.gov/programs/orr/) The Department of
Homeland Security (DHS) administers and funds the Cuban/Haitian program under
which Cubans are allowed into the US under the following immigration status Sec.
212(d)(5) of the I&N Act. This immigration status is similar to the refugee status
(Section 207 of the Act) but not quite. Refugees are exempt from paying USCIS
filing fees for adjustment of status. Parolees Sec. 212(d)(5) ? as mentioned
above ? are not and are required to adjust status after 1 year and 1 day in the US.
Thus, DHS first brings Parolees Sec. 212(d)(5) into the US, if they are lucky and
they have their work permit after 6 months they will have minimum wage jobs for
about 6 months and then are asked to pay to DHS filing fees for $905/person for
adjustment of status. How is that supposed to work? In addition, those
immigrants/parolees have to pay other fees: biometrics, medical exams and fees
for EAD (work permit, I-765). We are talking about at least $5,000 for a family of 4
who has been only 1 year in the country and was admitted by DHS. This is such
a contradiction and does not make sense. DHS is raising the fee for I-485 from
$325 to $905 with the argument of becoming more efficient? Who is going to
believe that?
The Parolees Sec. 212(d)(5) who are admitted to the US by DHS under the C/H
Entrant program are in fact refugees and should be treated as those under Section
207 of the Act and exempt from the filing fees. Please take this into consideration.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Dagmar Ruehring, Catholic Charities
